result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: To conserve the biodiversity in the Central Zagros Landscape Conservation Zone

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
%ge of the Zone under a management regime addressing mainstreaming biodiversity conservation( THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/ UNDP APPROVALS)
BIODIVERSITY RICH FOREST, RANGELAND AND RIPARIAN HABITATS ARE CONSERVED AND RESTORED IN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS ACCORDING TO SPECIFICATIONS AND AREAS MAPPED IN MANAGEMENT PLANS (NEW)

baseline.comment: BASELINE SURVEYS OF HABITATS IN PMA CONSERVATION & RESTORATION AREAS TO BE CONDUCTED

target.comment: HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS TOTALING AT LEAST 10,000 HA IN EACH PMA ESTABLISHED AND FUNCTIONING SUPPORTED BY FINANCING, PARTICIPATORY MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING MECHANISMS BY END OF 2016 (NEW)

actual.comment: - The total area of Central Zagros Mountains (CZM) under study was extended after revision from 2.500.000 ha to 3.100.000 ha and 10 catchment management areas (CMAs) were designated to be managed (Long-term and macro scale), and the scaling-up of the long term CZM management system started in 2 phases: First, in 2015, 4 PMAs, i.e. 393.465 ha, were extended to 4 CMAs with the total area of 1.629.000 ha. At the second phase, the remaining 6 CMAs (not included in the former PMAs), will be considered as a part of scaling up in 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Population of selected key flagship species (Persian squirrel and bear) ( THIS INDICATOR IS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/ UNDP APPROVALS)
POPULATION OF SELECTED FLAGSHIP SPECIES (FAUNA AND FLORA) IN BD HOTSPOTS ACROSS THE ZONE
CHANGE IN STATUS OF INDICATOR SPECIES IN PMA CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS RELATED TO THE FOLLOWING ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS:
a) RANGELAND DEGRADATION (SELECTED FLORA AND BUTTERFLY SPECIES SENSITIVE TO OVERGRAZING)
b) FOREST DEGRADATION AND LOSS (DENSITY OF REGENERATING SEEDLINGS OF DOMINANT TREE SPECIES (EG PERSIAN OAK))
c) RIVERINE HABITAT DEGRADATION (EURASIAN OTTER)
d) HUNTING PRESSURE (CHUKAR PARTRIDGE)
(NEW INDICATOR)

baseline.comment: TO BE DETERMINED THROUGH BASELINE SURVEYS IN SAMPLING AREAS

target.comment: STABLE OR INCREASING POPULATION TRENDS IN SAMPLING AREAS BY THE END OF 2016 (NEW)

actual.comment:
- A total of 940.60 ha, of forest and rangelands of the CZM has been occupied, fired, degreased, and charcoal made during this period of PIR, a two-fold reduction in comparison with the 2014 PIR.
- A total of 4300 ha of Oak forest inside CZM is rehabilitated by FRWO to recover the forest habitats which have been affected by Oak Die Back disease.
- Illegal hunting of birds is reported 10 numbers, also DoE reported the total number of watched choker partridgeâ€™ population 121 (Naghan-Boldagi),
- The population of Wild Goat is 4483 which has been raised for four times and the total number of chukar partridgeâ€™ population is 276 (West Dena),
- Rehabilitation 10 K.ms of Eurasian otter Habitat along Marbor River (Dena Vanak),
- The population of Wild goat in Margoon is 9 (Kor Kamfirouz),

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: ANNUAL RATE OF CONVERSION OF NATURAL HABITATS TO OTHER LAND USES WITHIN PMAS (NEW)

baseline.comment: TO BE DETERMINED USING GIS LAND COVER MAPPING

target.comment: ANNUAL RATE OF CONVERSION IS LESS THAN 50 HA / YEAR PER PMA

actual.comment:
- The amount of illegal land occupation in Naghan-Boldagi was about 49.5 as below: 7.5 ha in Miankooh, Ardal County about 17 ha and also 25 ha of the Dureh in Bozoft.
- The amount of illegal occupation of land in West Dena was 52.75 ha. As below: 11.65 ha of the land use change in Boyer Ahmad and 21.6 ha land degradation in Dena.
- The illegal change of the land use of the pastures to dry land farming of about 0.5 ha, seizing the pasture land in the form of planting of about 10 ha, 9 ha of which was for planting apple and 1 was for plowing the pasture.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: %100 non urban land subject to some regulations regarding conservation of biodiversity into development activities ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OUTCOME 2 INDICATORS BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: 2.500.000 ha (total central Zagros area)

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Mainstreaming conservation of BD in development activities (FRWO, Jihad Agri. Tourism Org., Energy, nomads, local communities, interior affair and all related activities have impact on BD) ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OUTCOME 2 AND 3 BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: 2.500.000 ha (total central Zagros area)

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: TRENDS IN AVERAGE SEDIMENT LOADS (TOTAL SUSPENDED SOLIDS) CARRIED BY MAJOR RIVERS ACROSS THE ZONE (NEW)

baseline.comment: TO BE DETERMINED FROM AVAILABLE DATA

target.comment: STABLE OR DECREASING TRENDS IN TSS BY END 2016

actual.comment:
- The average of TSS for the main rivers of Ch-B Province are: Sabzkooh 1.15 Mg/L (which it shows highly promotion in compare with 2013), Sangan, 0.83 Mg/L, Koohrang, 2.31 Mg/L, Samsami, 2.51 Mg/L, Dinaran, 2.49 Mg/L, Pirooz, 1.66 Mg/L,
- The average of moved sediment load in Boshar River increased for one-second in compare with 2013.

target.comment: a

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description:
Outcome 1:
A national institutional and policy framework that is fully supportive of mainstreaming biodiversity into development in central Zagros mountains.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
Number of MoUs signed and started implementing between DoE and Ministries of Agriculture and Energy, Cultural Heritage and Tourism Organization, and Tribal Affairs Organisation ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BY MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
PROPOSALS FOR POLICY IMPROVEMENTS SUPPORTING MAINSTREAMING OF BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION INTO DEVELOPMENT OF THE ZAGROS MOUNTAINS DRAFTED AND SUBMITTED TO NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE ENTITIES FOR CONSIDERATION (NEW)

baseline.comment: PROPOSAL FOR ASSESSMENT OF EXISTING LEGAL & POLICY FRAMEWORK DRAFTED

target.comment: END OF 2015/ START OF 2016

actual.comment: - Conservation and Sustainable Development Programme (C + SD) of Central Zagros Mountains (CZM) was developed and finalized based on the received feedbacks from the stakeholders at three levels: National/ Provincial/ Local. This document was approved by Project Board's.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Approved Strategy for development incorporating biodiversity ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDPAPPROVALS)
NATIONAL/SUB-NATIONAL PROGRAMME BD CONSERVATION IN ZAGROS MOUNTAINOUS LANDSCAPES APPROVED BY NATIONAL LEGISLATIVE ENTITIES AND OPERATIONAL INCLUDING REQUIRED BUDGET AND MONITORING FRAMEWORKS (NEW)

target.comment: END OF 2015/ START OF 2016

actual.comment: - C+SD program finalized, and submitted to I.R Cabinet/ High council of Environment and MPO for approval, designation, and to be funded in the 6th five years National development plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Central level and provincial level mechanisms for intersectoral planning and coordination for conservation of MEMLs (THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
A MANAGEMENT SYSTEM FOR CENTRAL ZAGROS MOUNTAINS IS FORMALLY ESTABLISHED AND LEGALLY DESIGNATED AS AN INTEGRATED MULTI-SECTOR RESOURCE INCLUDING SCALE UP STRATEGY, NATIONAL POLICIES AND LAWS FRAMEWORK.(NEW)

target.comment: End of 2015

actual.comment: - Design CZM Management System and finalize scale up strategy (for the long term and large scale CMAs), and submit the proposal to Cabinet and PPDCs (in four provinces) to designate CMAs and establish the CZM management system, and also process budget allocation to national and provincial CZM Executive Secretariats through 6th five years National Development Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Conservation of Zagros biodiversity mentioned in at least 2 sectors : Agriculture and Natural Resources in 5th Five Year Plan with clear objectives ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
A PERMANENT GOVERNING BODY (NATIONAL AND PROVINCIAL) FOR THE CZM REGION SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT/ MANAGEMENT IS FORMALLY DESIGNATED AND ESTABLISHED. (NEW)

baseline.comment: NO PERMANENT OFFICE OR AGENCY IS DESIGNATED.

target.comment: END OF 2015/ START OF 2016

actual.comment: - The CZM governing body/ management system in national/ provincial/ and CMA levels, is designed as a part of existing Iranâ€™s governing system (by some modifications and adaptations), and work is under way to have this completely adopted with CSD Programme by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Investment incentives for sustainable harvesting of biodiversity resources (THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OUTCOME 3 BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: Target to be set by mid-2009 and following the finalization of the BD valuation study

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Government financial commitments made available and disbursed (THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OUTCOME 3 BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: 100% of pledged co-financing by end of the project

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: The Project Board include high level representation from different sectors and these board members will integrate BD conservation into their plans for the Zagros mountains (THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OUTCOME 3 BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: 2 meetings each year
a

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Outcome 2: Sustainable use and conservation of biodiversity integrated into economic and sectoral programmes and government practices at the conservation zone level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
% reduction of unsustainable harvesting of non wood forests products such as medicinal herbs and aromatic plants % of nomad families adopt improved grazing and livelihood practices ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
CATALOGUE OF EVALUATED RESOURCE MATERIALS FOR 50+ INCOME GENERATION AND LIVELIHOOD OPTIONS AVAILABLE FOR RURAL AND NOMAD COMMUNITIES IN CENTRAL ZAGROS.(NEW)

baseline.comment: NO SYSTEMATIC APPROACH TO SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS PLANNING OR DEVELOPMENT

target.comment:
FIRST VERSION OF CATALOGUE IN 2014
50% nomad families in the pilot areas adopt alternative/green enterprises by the end of the project

actual.comment: - Information materials and catalog for sustainable resource enterprises and livelihoods within CZM is developed through survey and analysis of livelihood options in 120 villages of CZM, and introduced and disseminated through CZM Information Management System.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: No. of the Forest Rangelands and Watershed Management Organization nature conservation projects jointly managed with DoE in Zagros ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REMOVED AND INCORPORATED IN OBJECTIVE AND OUTCOME 3 BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)

target.comment: Start of full-scale CZM CA/ BR in 2015

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Reduction in littering of major touristic spots of the region (eg Margoon and Behesht-e Gomshodeh) as a proxy indicator of more BD conscious tourism (THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
INFORMATION AND ADVICE ON A RANGE OF ECOLOGICALLY-SUSTAINABLE RESOURCE ENTERPRISES AND LIVELIHOODS OPTIONS IN THE CZM ARE WIDELY AVAILABLE TO LOCAL AND PROVINCIAL STAKEHOLDERS. (NEW)

baseline.comment: NO SYSTEMATIC DEVELOPMENT AND DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION ON SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOOD OPTIONS.

target.comment: LIVELIHOODS INFORMATION IN USE ACROSS CZM IN 2015.

actual.comment:
- Information materials and catalogue for sustainable resource enterprises and livelihoods within CZM is developed through survey and analysis of livelihood options in 120 villages of CZM, and wildly introduced and disseminated through CZM Information Management System.
- The concept papers for green development and sustainable resource use initiatives including green agriculture/ fisheries/ water and waste/ rangeland/ forest/ tourism/ landscape/ Village/ Livelihood and sustainable life of nomads, have been drafted, and the participatory development of green projects, is initiated in each province.
- The piloting of B. E. Grant Scheme is completed, and the proposal for the long term and large scale is drafted, and submitted to PPDCs for approval, funding and implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
% increase in awareness and understanding on the importance of Zagros biodiversity among provincial level planners and policy makers (THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
INFORMATION AND MANAGEMENT TOOLS ARE IN USE, ASSISTING EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT NATURAL RESOURCE PLANNING AND CONSERVATION ACROSS THE CZM REGION (NEW)

baseline.comment: DATA COLLECTION, ANALYSIS AND PLANNING CARRIED OUT SEPARATELY BY EACH RESOURCE SECTOR.

target.comment: RESOURCE CONSERVATION INFORMATION SYSTEM IN USE ACROSS CZM IN 2015

actual.comment: - CZM Management Toolkit including; Sustainable Resource Use Guidelines, CZM Ecological Land Use Plan and Monitoring Plan and System, is drafted and incorporated and disseminated through CZM Management Information System and CZM Resource Centers. In parallel, the Capacity Development Plan for CZM Management System drafted and is under implementation to empower CZM stakeholders for integrated and sustainable use and management of all resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description:
No of provinces currently under project adopt measures, approaches and practices developed under this project (THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
MANAGEMENT OF ALL NATURAL RESOURCES AND SITES ACROSS THE CENTRAL ZAGROS MOUNTAINS REGION ARE INCORPORATED WITHIN THE CZM. (NEW)

target.comment: START OF FULL-SCALE CZM CA/ BR IN 2015

actual.comment:
- Design 10 CMAs within CZM as an ecological and integrated management units, and process development the guide for integrated and co-management of CMAs including draft CMAsâ€™ maps and profiles.
- The piloting of development PMAs annual WP is completed and reported under outcome 3, and scaling up of development of the annual integrated work plan for the first priority CMAs, is under implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: EXISTENCE OF FORMALLY ESTABLISHED AND OPERATIONAL INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCES MANAGEMENT MECHANISMS FOR FOUR PROVINCES IN THE CENTRAL ZAGROS (NEW)

baseline.comment: PPDCS MANDATED TO COORDINATE ECONOMIC PLANNING, BUT INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IS NOT FUNCTIONING IN REALITY

target.comment: BY END 2015

actual.comment:
- Preparatory/ bilateral/ and consultancy meetings for establishment of CZM management committees and secretariats are as bellow;
o Head of DoE, as a secretary of High Council of Environment and chair of CZM National Committee for Sustainable Development (CZM National Management Committee),
o Provincial GGs as a chair of CZM provincial management committees,
o Planning and Budgeting Deputy of GGs as a head of CZM provincial secretariat,
o County Governors of first priority CMAs, as a chair of CMA Management Committees,
o The national/ provincial/ and local authorities as a member of CZM management committees in different levels,
- As a results of above meetings could be:
o Approval for CZM CSD Programme by Project Board,
o Initiate the establishment of CZM Provincial Executive Secretariats by GGs of four provinces,
o Initiate up scaling the four PMAsâ€™ LPCs to the first priority four CMAsâ€™ Management Committees including Kor, Vanak-Khersan, Dena and Bazoft CMAs;

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: FUNCTIONAL MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SYSTEM AND TOOLS IN PLACE IN FOUR PROVINCES; SUPPORTING ZM REGION PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT. (NEW)

baseline.comment: NO ORGANISED INFORMATION SYSTEM FOR CZM

target.comment: BY END 2015

actual.comment: - Conduct study on ecological capacity assessment of CZM and CMAs, and data collection and organization through the single designed CZM Information Management System, and negotiate with Provincial DoEs to upload the system and wildly make it available for all stakeholders, and plan to build the capacity for CZM management committees and secretariat to use, update and support the Information System,

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: SUPPORTIVE MECHANISMS FOR BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND INTEGRATED BIODIVERSITY RESOURCE MANAGEMENT IN THE CENTRAL ZAGROS (THE SECTOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES WITH SUSTAINABILITY GUIDELINES (FORESTRY, WATER, GRAZING, AQUACULTURE, TOURISM, ETC), BE GRANT SCHEME AND CZ RCS) ARE INSTITUTIONALIZED, ADEQUATELY RESOURCED AND FULLY OPERATIONAL. (NEW)

baseline.comment: NO SECTOR MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES IN PLACE

target.comment: BY END 2015

actual.comment:
- Develop and publish nine sustainability resource use guidelines including Water Resource, Agriculture, Aquaculture, Forest, Rangeland, Tourism, Solid Waste and Effluent Management, and EIA.
- The results of piloting B. E. Grant Scheme is approval and allocating budget to four submitted proposals (two ecotourism, one rangeland conservation and one mushroom planting project) by LPCs, and implementation the above projects by NGOs and CBOs in Dena Vanak and Naghan PMAs, also approval of two submitted proposal by LPC in West Dena.
- Establish and activate the Zagros Mountains Resource Centers (ZMRCs) in the 4 provinces with collaboration of local NGOs, and also support the RCâ€™s links in the DoEs' portals of Fars, Isfahan, Kohgiloye va Boyerahamad and Chaharmahalo Bakhtiari

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Outcome 3: Successful, sustainable, financially replicable models of village designed and driven approaches to increasing income generation and conserving biodiversity in biodiversity rich areas coordination, monitoring, advocacy and adaptive management

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
% increase in household income at pilot village (THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/GEFRO APPROVALS)
PRIORITY CONSERVATION ACTIONS IMPLEMENTED AND EVALUATED IN EACH PILOT MA. STRATEGIC PILOT LIVELIHOOD INITIATIVES IMPLEMENTED AND EVALUATED IN EACH PILOT MA. (NEW)

target.comment: END OF 2014/ START OF 2015

actual.comment:
- Implementation seven conservation and sustainable livelihood projects namely:
o â€œWild and bird watchingâ€ in West Dena, including forming the Local Tour Guide CBO (15 villagers from 3 villages), provide equipment and establish one eco-lodge and entertain one tour within the village and encourage the hunters to be more familiar with the wildlife.
o Develop sustainable livelihood action plan in Naqan-Buldaji and build the capacity of 45 rural female and 56 rural male from four villages for development ecological livelihood namely planting medical herbs, carpet, mushroom, beekeeping, compost, sewing local clothes.
o â€œsustainable ecotourismâ€ in Kor-Kamfirouz including build capacity for 20 rural youth as CBO in Mengan Village, equip and establish three eco-lodge, wild watching cottages and handicraft shop, and also entertain four groups of visitors.
o â€œRural Handicrafts developmentâ€ in Naqan-Buldaji including capacity development for the 20 female villagers and forming the Sholiz CBO, conduct local/ provincial and national handicraft exhibitions, marketing and provide income for female villagers and involve them in rehabilitation of Oak forest.
o "Rehabilitation and conservation of medical herbs" in Dena Vanakincluding planting of 12000 seeds of Dracocephalum kotschyi Boiss & Thymus daenenss, and build the capacity for 10 nomads and support them in marketing,
o â€œ2nd phase of IPCM (Integrated Participatory Crop Management)â€ in Kor-Kamfirouz, including establish six CBO (25 villagers in each group) through infrastructures in 6 core villages. The result has been disseminated to all CZM provinces by the MOJA to be included in their annual program.
o Conduct the study for â€œAnalyzing the effect of environmental factors on the implementation of the fungi in the mass of Oak Forest die back in Iranâ€ in West Dena by the cooperation of FRWO. Based on the first report Yasuj University came to this idea that the bacteria as the secondary factor in Oak Die Back not a Fungi.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
Significant improvement in BD status surrounding 8 pilot villages (Proxy indicator: recruitments/regeneration of oak species in forests adjacent to pilot villages ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
BIODIVERSITY RICH HABITATS ARE CONSERVED AND RESTORED IN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS ACCORDING TO SPECIFICATIONS AND AREAS MAPPED IN MANAGEMENT PLANS (NEW)

target.comment: HABITAT CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION AREAS TOTALING AT LEAST 10,000 HA IN EACH PMAS IDENTIFIED, MAPPED AND OBJECTIVES ESTABLISHED; AND MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED FOR FINANCING, PARTICIPATORY MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING BY END OF 2016

actual.comment:
- Conservation and rehabilitation of 438 ha. of Oak die back forest in Naghan-Boldagi, and also approval and designate Sabzkouh Biosphere Reserve (532878 ha.) by UNESCO Head Quarter,
- Protection of rangeland is 1911 ha. In Dena and 3500 ha. in Boyerahmad, also conservation of Oak forest is 880 in Dena and 2187 ha in Boyerahmad.
- Rehabilitation of 60 Km. of Boshar River banks, and 10 Km. of Marbor River,
- Rehabilitation and development of 440 ha. of Oak forest, and also protection of 4000 ha. of damaged rangeland in Dena Vanak,
- Watershed management to control 1000 qubic meters erosion in Dena Vank,
- Control unsustainable tourism in Tange Bostanak, and rehabilitation of 400 ha. of Oak forest in Kor,

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Local participation in conservation activities increased (Proxy indicator: number of village conservation groups formed and started to take responsibility to protect forests adjacent to their village ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
LEVEL OF SUPPORT FOR BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION INCREASES WITHIN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS AS INDICATED BY THE NUMBER OF LOCAL CONSERVATION GROUPS FORMED AND ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES (NEW)

target.comment: - AT LEAST 8 LOCAL CONSERVATION GROUPS BY END 2016

actual.comment:
- Ten local conservation groups established as follows:
o The female CBO â€œSholizâ€ (with 20 members), in Gelsefid Village. This CBO has 4 working groups to produce and sold the handicrafts; also they were engage in rehabilitating the 18 ha. of Oak forest.
o â€œQalbe Denaâ€ (Dena's Heart) as a local eco tour guide CBO with 15 active villagers from three villages namely, Khoongah, Ab Sepah and Dashte Raz,
o Forming 6 â€œVolunteer IPCM CBOsâ€ from 3 villages of kor namely Bakian, Sarbast and Hosseinabad, and 3 villages in Kamfirouz namely Abbasabad, Chogha, and Mansoorabad (each CBO has 25 members, and the total is 150 villagers),
o "Doostdarane Tabiate Bekre Gomshode" CBO as a first volunteer group of Kor, which is involved in ZMRC in Fars Province,
o â€œGardeshgarie Paydare Roostaye Mangen", as a local tour guide CBO with 20 members in Mengan Village.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
% of provincial (sector/partner) agencies adopt participatory and community driven resource planning and management developed approaches by the project ( THIS INDICATOR WAS REVISED AS BELOW BASED ON MTE AND PB/UNDP APPROVALS)
FOUR PILOT MA MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES AND ACTION PROGRAMS OPERATING EFFICIENTLY WITH ACTIVE SUPPORT BY PROJECT STAFF (NEW)

baseline.comment: LPCS ARE FUNCTIONED AND PLANNING INITIATED.

target.comment: END OF 2014/ START OF 2015

actual.comment: - Development and implementation of PMA annual work plan by LPCs in four PMAs , also following complementary budget allocation by PPDCs in four provinces,

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Project management and institutional structure including TORs

target.comment: Project setup in place andfunctioning

actual.comment:
- Strengthening and restructure the human resources of project by:
o Redevelop ToR and recruitment two Technical Expert- Management, Planning and Law (instead of communication and landscape planning experts), and one Technical Expert- Capacity Development (instead of public awareness raising expert),
o Develop ToR and recruitment six national consultants to develop Green Initiatives,

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Project plans (Annual and Quarterly Work Plans, M&E Plan, Communication Strategy and Action Plan, etc.) prepared in time and duly implemented

target.comment: One AWP, 4QWAs per year. One Annual Progress Report per year

actual.comment:
- AWP 2014, audit action plan, M&E Framework and QWPs, and annually and quarterly progress reports prepared on time.
- Two Project Board meeting held in 2014 which the 2013 annual progress, AWP 2014, monitoring frameworks and C+SD Programme were discussed and approved.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: SPECIFIC LOCAL WATER POLLUTION PROBLEMS IDENTIFIED IN PILOT MANAGEMENT AREAS MANAGEMENT PLANS ARE PROGRESSIVELY REDUCED IN PMAS THROUGH PARTICIPATORY APPROACHES (NEW)

target.comment: 10% ANNUAL DECREASE IN REPORTED POLLUTION PROBLEMS FROM 2013

actual.comment:
- The average of TSS for the main rivers of Ch-B Province are: Sabzkooh 1.15 Mg/L (which it shows highly promotion in compare with 2013), Sangan, 0.83 Mg/L, Koohrang, 2.31 Mg/L, Samsami, 2.51 Mg/L, Dinaran, 2.49 Mg/L, Prooz, 1.66 Mg/L,
- The average of moved sediment load in Boshar River increased for one-second in compare with 2013,

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: ZAGROS PROJECT PILOT PROGRAM COMPLETED EFFECTIVELY. RESULTS OF PILOT EVALUATED, UNDERSTOOD BY NATIONAL AND PROVINCIAL DECISION-MAKERS, AND APPLIED TO THE DESIGN OF THE FULL-SCALE CZM CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. (NEW)

target.comment: BY END 2015

actual.comment:
- The Zagros Project Pilot Programme, completed and evaluated by all stakeholders in four provinces. The report of evaluation of piloting phase includes achievements and lessons, and directly used in design CZM Management System, development long term C+SD Programme and design large scale and permanent CMAs,
- The Pilot Programme report was submitted and approved by Project Board. Refer to IA mission report, 2014 Annual Report, and Pilot Programme Evaluation & Lessons Report, â€œOutcome 3â€, is partially completed in 2014, and also is modified and planned under outcome 2 (Outputs 2.1 and 2.2) to ensure sustainability and up scaling of Pilot Management Areas to permanent CZM Catchment Management Areas,

iati-activity.description: Removal of barriers to climate-resilient integrated natural resource management in Iran by providing coordination mechanism, policies, inventories of good practice, degradation assessments and Integrated Natural Resource Management training

result.title: Objective
result.description: To remove barriers to Integrated Natural Resources Management (INRM) by developing and strengthening gender-sensitive institutional knowledge, capacity and coordination, and by demonstrating and up-scaling successful sustainable land and water management practices that address gender concerns as well

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Hectares of land where climate-resilient, INRM is demonstrated for further replication in other areas

target.comment: 40,000 hectares of land where MENARID approach is demonstrated through cross-sectoral mechanism

actual.comment: 40000 ha are under MENARID approach already reached and in addition PB approved that MENARID replicated in Khorasan province and seven provinces in the Karoon river basin. Total hectares of land will reported next year.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Overall decrease in trend and/or severity of land degradation as measured by no. of hectares under SLM practices

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: 4000 hectares at 4 demonstration sites under SLM

actual.comment: 3856 ha (1989 ha new in this reporting period) at 4 demonstration sites are under SLM

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Enhanced carbon sequestration in soil and vegetation across landscape in project demonstration sites

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: 60,000 tons increase of total system carbon at 4 demonstration sites

actual.comment: 37076 tons CS (25076 tons new in this reporting period) through rangeland rehabilitation and reduced deforestation through installing solar water heaters at 4 demonstration sites

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Enhanced resilience to climate change at demonstration site due to adaptation and mitigation measures (e.g. resistant varieties, vegetative buffers, and wind erosion control)*
No. of project participants (women and men) in demonstration sites who are vulnerable to either LD, CC, IW and BD loss as measured through membership to community groups*

baseline.comment: 0 hec, Total: 3039 (active population in project pilot sites)

target.comment:
At least four types of resilience-enhancing measures employed in 10,000 hec at 4 demonstration sites
50% of vulnerable resident population between 18 years -60 years (women and men) in 12 villages at demonstration sites involved in project through community groups (Village Development Committees, women groups, etc.)

actual.comment:
5 types of resilience-enhancing measures employed in 13714 ha at 4 demonstration sites that include;
Wind erosion control in Sistan: 50 ha (20 ha new in this reporting period), Flood control and Soil erosion control 12500 ha (5000 ha in Kermanshah and 6000 ha in Hable-e-rud are new in this reporting period), sustainable agriculture 40 ha (33 ha in Kermanshah and 7 ha in Yazd are new in this reporting period), cultivation resistance species, (Medical plant cultivation, wild almond cultivation, pistachio and saffron cultivation to use less water): 1124 ha, (1024ha new in this reporting period). Totally 2208 persons (361 new persons (men and women) involved in the project management .

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Overarching improvement in water resource management, quality and availability through appropriate demonstration project execution

baseline.comment: Weak policies, communication & coordination resulting in fragile or non-existent IWRM & WUE approaches in place

target.comment: 4 projects on IWRM in 12 villages at demonstration sites to lead towards WUE Strategy

actual.comment: 7 projects in 8 villages that include; Rehabilitation of around 2700 meters of Qanat in Amid Abad (hable-e-rud basin), improving water irrigation efficiency through rehabilitation of 1600 meters irrigation channels in Asad Abad. 700 ha watershed management in Razin of Kermanshah, rehabilitation of 1340 meters of Qanat in Karimabad-Yazd. Increase water efficiency of agricultural through water transfer pipes in Kamkoyeh 1340 meters and 1000 meters in Karimabad, constructing a forestry park 100 ha based on rain harvesting methodology in vahdat abad Yazd, Sediment removal in Sarabshahhousein river 60000 cubic meters, project is going to prepare a joint program between water agency and agriculture center to improve irrigation efficiency which will cover 2800 ha that include 22 villages in hable-e-rud site.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced engendered knowledge and understanding of the drivers of land-use change causing land, ecosystem and water degradation with consequent impacts on ecosystem services and local livelihoods

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: The project includes gender analysis of drivers of land-use change causing land, ecosystem and water degradation, and measures to identify and address women's specific needs and contributions in INRM.

target.comment: Gender analysis report in demonstration sites

actual.comment: All the project reports include gender analytical report. as the reports have been shown, none of the land change drivers are based on gender issues.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: There is evidence of increased public awareness at national, provincial and local levels on INRM, gendered impact of environmental finance and the multiplier effects of financing womenâ€™s productive activities.

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured in Y1

target.comment: Increased awareness at different levels on INRM, and gendered impact of environmental finance and the multiplier effects of financing womenâ€™s productive activities, as measured through No. of articles/ news in print and TV media, attendance in conferences, seminars, workshops on above, and no. of requests on further information.

actual.comment:
10% increased national awareness on INRM and gendered impact of environmental finance and the multiplier effects of financing womenâ€™s productive activities, through the following activities:
-Publication and distribution of 1000 copies of 3 newsletters.
-Publication and distribution of 2 Guidebooks.
-1 introductory documentary broadcasted by National TV.
- 12 news on project achievements were published in news agencies.
- 1 thematic documentary produced on Hamoon.
- 465 meters of graffiti were done in Sistan that include 10 slogans on INRM.
- 3636 visitors visited project website.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Gender â€“sensitive monitoring and information system on dry land agriculture, and drought early warning system for land-use change, and land and water degradation assessment

target.comment: System developed and verified on drought early warning system; PGIS/GIS techniques applied on gender sensitive monitoring and information system.

actual.comment: A land monitoring software put in place to test possibilities of gender sensitive monitoring and information system. also project wants to see whether it is possible to input those PGIS that have done to this software to reach a system that be sensitive to gender issues.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of engendered NRM and water management best practices characterized in 4 provinces

target.comment: At least 3 practices per province with capability for up scaling; most derived from demonstration or adjacent sites.

actual.comment: Target achieved and best practices documentation are on the progress. project hopes with documenting and publishing best practices make the field ready for them to repeat and become able to influence on the policies gradually.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of market-based (financial), non-monetary and trade-off assessments of the loss of ecosystems services (provisioning, regulating, cultural) in 4 provinces

target.comment: Four comprehensive, integrated assessments of market based, non-monetary and trade-off in ecosystem services.

actual.comment: Completion of four comprehensive, integrated assessments were reported in last year PIR and in this reporting period two analytical reports on "cost of land degradation at watershed level in 4 pilot sites" and "land degradation prioritization in 3 pilot sites using LADA methodology" were prepared.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: An enabling environment for INRM and the use of the enhanced knowledge from Component 1

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of institutional mechanisms on natural resource planning and coordination working cross-sectorally at national, provincial and local levels

baseline.comment:
National: 1 *
Provincial: 4 *
Local: 0
* see R&A col.

target.comment:
National: 2 active
Provincial: 4 active
Local: 4 active

actual.comment:
National: 2 active cross-sectoral mechanisms (PB, GEF projects network) Provincial: 8 active (Technical and M&E at each 4 project sites)
Sub-provincial: 4 (Watershed levels at each project sites)
Local: 9 at village level
since project practice showed that INRM think tank wasn't functional, it was closed.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Cross-sectoral mechanism for INRM established at national level to link SLM and IWRM planning processes

target.comment: One

actual.comment: This indicator removed by MTE

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Government agencies and representatives of community organizations are systematically engaged in dialogue on INRM

target.comment: One institutional mechanism is established at each province including representative from communities, government and other stakeholders

actual.comment: 4 institutional mechanisms (one at national level (project board), two at provincial level (Technical committee and monitoring and planning committee) and one at township level(watershed management committee) are established that representatives of government organizations, NGOs and local communities especially women CBOs participated in their meetings.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Community organizations, including those representing marginalized, established to contribute actively to planning, implementation and management processes for INRM.

target.comment: 37 active groups of women and men are established

actual.comment: 52 groups of women and men were established (15 groups new in this reporting period) actively involved in INRM sub-project management

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Women are consulted in policy-making processes so that their knowledge and interests are reflected in INRM.

target.comment: One consultation mechanism is established

actual.comment: 3 consultation mechanisms were established (project board, monitoring and planning committee and watershed management committee) that representatives of women CBOs participated in.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Number of policies on approaches and practices involving INRM arising from activities at the project demonstration sites

target.comment: At least three strategy documents (one per demonstration site)

actual.comment: No changes in this year because editing the strategic documents that mentioned last year took more time that project expecte. so project couldn't plan any implement ion base on the documents..

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Number of requests and/or database access events for information on INRM originating from national and provincial stakeholders and other relevant parties, including the private sector and other projects

target.comment:
Originating from:
National: 100
Local/prov: 50 each
others 20

actual.comment:
At national level; based on requests of ministry of cooperatives, labor and social welfare and national NGOs network, MENARID INRM practices were presented to these stakeholders via two separate seminars.
Based on request of technical deputies (60 persons) and general directors (32 persons) of FRWO, 2 workshops were held that MENARID approaches were presented through.
Based on request of joint secretariat of international projects in IRAN the experiences of MENARID in marketing were presented to the members.
At provincial level 3 universities (Gorgan, Sari and Mashhad) requested MENARID information and reports.
From lots of requests for visiting MENARID practices, finally 150 experts from different level havevisited project pilot sites.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community-driven, climate-resilient approaches and techniques for sustainable land and water management demonstrated through INRM practices

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Increase in global environmental benefits with co-benefits for local development in demonstration sites

target.comment:
a. 73,000 tons of carbon, valuing USD416,000 (@US5.7 per ton) through sequestration of 60,000 tons and emission reduction of 13,000 tons of carbon
b. Two (2) PES mechanisms support conservation and promote biodiversity-friendly alternative livelihoods at demonstration sites
c. 4 sub projects at demonstration sites for rehabilitation of irrigation and rain fed areas of 4000 hectares rehabilitated and delivering 30% increased water use efficiency
d. 4 sub projects at demonstration site for improving resilience to climate change forest and rangelands cover in project area increased by 10%

actual.comment:
a. the project has contributed to climate change mitigation through sequestrating 37076 tons of carbon
b.4 PES mechanisms put in place; Conservation of biodiversity project (rangeland management to conserve plant diversity in Behabad site in Yazd Province), Payment for carbon sequestration (implementation of regulating line, planting trees and water management in Razin site in Kermanshah Province), Payment for countering land degradation (planting of tamarisk, in degraded agricultural lands in order to counter the encroachment of moving sand in Hamoun site in Sistan and Baluchestan Province), -Payment for increasing water use efficiency (repair and restoration of qanat in Amidabad village in Semnan Province)
c.6 projects on rehabilitation of irrigation and rain fed were done; Rehabilitation of around 2700 meters of Qanat in Amid Abad (hable-e-rud basin), improving water irrigation efficiency through rehabilitation of 1600 meters irrigation channels in Asad Abad. 700 ha watershed management in Razin of Kermanshah, rehabilitation of 1340 meters of Qanat in Karimabad-Yazd. Increase water efficiency of agricultural through water transfer pipes in Kamkoyeh 1340 meters and 1000 meters in Karimabad, constructing a forestry park 100 ha based on rain harvesting
d. 5 rangeland management cases (2 new in this reporting period) in Kermanshah (170 ha), Yazd (130 ha) and Hable-rud (3300 ha) were done totaly..

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in best-practice, organic and traditional/local innovations in land and water management, biodiversity conservation and climate change resilience ,

target.comment: 8 innovations at demonstration sites

actual.comment:
8 innovations at demonstration sites were established (one new in this reporting period that is producing 4 solar driers to demonstrate in each pilot sites)
Traditionally extra vegetable and fruits were dried to be kept for a longer course of time. The system they used to it is not hygienic, market acceptable, and healthy. Solar food dehydrator is a simple set which led the farmer to dry their materials in dust and insect free environment. Fruits and vegetable are dried in shade to keep their essential oils and vitamins. It help rural to take benefit of sun and there is no need of other sources such as fuel which is getting more expensive these days. This set is suitable for a gardener who has one or more fruit garden. Result of primarily tests is satisfactory and local people are interested to make more sets for their own

target.comment: Increased by at least 30%

actual.comment: This indicators removed by MTE

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: IWRM and WUE strategies in place, with institutional ownership secured and best approaches mainstreamed into national and regional planning frameworks by end of project

baseline.comment:
Weak policies, communication & coordination resulting in fragile or non-existent IWRM approaches in place
Water Use Efficiency is poorly understood and often not considered in water management decisions

target.comment: IWRM and Water Use Efficiency Strategies in place. Technical, management, participatory and advocacy lessons from demonstration sites developed into presentation packages with best practices mainstreamed into national and regional approaches by end of project

actual.comment: Two Water Use Efficiency Strategies were prepared by participation of local communities, water agency, Jahad-e agriculture, natural resource organization and project technical experts in Tehran province. Base on these strategies an organization established that named Ab Baran that those farmers who are responsible for water management are its members. This organization is responsible for implementing the strategies.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of PES schemes established (or firmly planned) that bring benefits for local livelihoods through INRM

target.comment: Four

actual.comment: 4 PES schemes established (2 PES new in this reporting period) that include constructing 17 solar water heater in Yazd and Qanat rehabilitation in Amidabad in Hable-e-rud

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Measures are in place, including affirmative action, to increase access by women-led businesses and womens organizations to finance for INRM.

target.comment: Four

actual.comment:
21 women-led businesses being developed (7 new in this reporting period), these groups could create 258 jobs for women.
such as: land renting to plant vegetables (it includes packaging, marketing and selling them in Behabad market), weaving carpet, producing and packaging medical plants esence, opening rural super market, two barber shops for women, producing and packaging rural products such as Kashke Zard and Achar... and producing 180000 potted seedling.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Climate change and mitigation policies and programmes are developed that reflect women's concerns and interests, and are monitored for their impact on women's lives so that equality of outcome is achieved.

target.comment: Four

actual.comment:
No changes
those women-led business that were established and reported last year continue their business.

target.comment: Four

actual.comment: This indicator removed by MTE

result.title: Objective
result.description: To put in place a collaborative governance system and know-how for managing a mosaic of land uses in the Caspian Hyrcanian forest that provides habitat integrity and helps maintain landscape level ecosystem functions and resilience.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Landscape area in the Caspian Hyrcanian forests where forestry and other production activities mainstream biodiversity conservation

target.comment: Policy and regulatory frameworks for managing multiple use forest landscapes across~ 800,000 ha of forests

actual.comment: Policy and regulatory frameworks have been reviewed through project financial resources to explore gaps for integration and mainstreaming of participatory multipurpose forestry and biodiversity conservation in sectoral policies, laws and regulations as well as institutional mechanisms such as monitoring and law enforcement systems. The study is at the final stages and it's expected to suggest amendments to policies, laws and regulations and institutional mechanisms. The study suggests that there are almost no barrier in policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to prevent FRWO and other government agencies to apply participatory forest management. The study is also encouraging the parliament to approve the national "Comprehensive Natural Resources Law" which is awaiting the final steps in there. A number of suggestions will come out of the study to enrich the regulatory framework of forest management. These suggestions will go to the Forest High Council for further action and taking into practice. In addition, the project contributed to development of relevant articles of the 6th National Development Plan and incorporated participatory multipurpose forestry in its draft version as a mandate for all government sectors during 2016-20.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Area of biodiversity set-asides created governed by clear specific management guidelines

baseline.comment: Some areas (~ 10%) are under biodiversity set-asides but without any systematic management regime for biodiversity conservation

target.comment: At least 100,000 ha of new biodiversity set asides under FRWO management defined (with management guidelines)

actual.comment: FRWO is managing Forest Reserves and Forest Parks in which rare plant species are conserved and protected. The idea of BD Set-asides puts forward a holistic mechanism through which both Fauna and Flora are under management regimes by FRWO. Aiming at developing management regimes for better management of biodiversity in the whole Caspian Hyrcanina Area, "Special Areas for Biodiversity" - SABs will be established in consultation with FRWO technical divisions and DoE as the main relevant stakeholder. SABs will be managed based on modern Biosphere Reserve model to ensure conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity (Fauna and Flora). A concept note has been developed on designing and management of SABs which was consulted in an inclusive biodiversity workshop. Potential SABs have been initially mapped by relevant stakeholders and draft codes of practice prepared in a participatory manner. Potential sites will be further studied and 100,000 ha of area will be assigned and designated as SABs by Forest High Council by mid-2016. Further steps will be taken to register SABs as biosphere reserves after the approval of the Forest High-Council.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Improvement in Total Capacity Development Scorecard (Annex V)

target.comment:
26 at the mid-term evaluatiuon course
42 at the final evaluation course

actual.comment: CD Scorecards were updated through consultation with the project team and stakeholders through which a cumulative score of 10 was calculated again. A Capacity Development Plan was drafted by the project, which will be further improved though consultation with stakeholders and the project team, specially at the local level has been the main development change during the reporting period. Furthermore, holding consultative Integrated Management Plan sessions in pilot landscapes in which representatives of all stakeholder groups including local communities is considered as a very effective capacity development tool for engagement of multiple stakeholders in planning. Impacts of these capacity development practices will be measured in the mid-term of the project implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Extent and quality of forest cover IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

baseline.comment:
Incidents of illicit felling involving creaming of commercially important species;
Clearance of forest areas for agriculture leading to 0.5% loss of forests

target.comment: No net loss of forest cover and improved quality with reduced loss of high grade species

actual.comment: Forest degradation is not only due to deforestation but also is mainly because of depletion of the forest quality. There is no single indicator based on which one can assess the quality of forest. Therefore, further to conducting forest cover assessment through remote sensing methods, the project arranged a comprehensive forest condition assessment through which 16 different forest parameters were measured. The field study is finished and report writing is in final stages. Forest quality parameters have been measured in pilot landscapes in the FRWO network of permanent monitoring plots with an area of 1,000 square meters. Forest cover and biodiversity parameters were also measured in the same network to be attributable. The study will be repeated at the end of the project implementation for comparing results.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

baseline.comment: SPECIES AND BASELINE TO BE SET IN 2014

target.comment: NO DECLINE IN STATUS OF RARE OR FLAGSHIP SPECIES IN PILOT LANDSCAPES BY END OF PROJECT

actual.comment: No change is expected to be measured in this stage. Based on discussions with the biodiversity consultants as well as project CTA and approval of project board changes of biodiversity status and trends could not be measured in short periods. Hence biodiversity survey will be repeated at the end of the project to assess the changes against the baseline. Status of mammals is under study in all four pilot landscapes. The study is focused on a few number of flagship species like Red Deer, Roe Deer, Persian Leopard, Wolf, Wild Boar and Brown Bear. Mammals study is also addressing human-wildlife conflicts which is a very important cause for killing of animals and will be concluded with a plan for conflict resolution in each of the pilot landscapes.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: An enabling policy and regulatory framework for multiple use forest management is developed

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: INTER-SECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED, National policy and regulatory framework is adjusted to meet BD mainstreaming requirements and is updated within operational procedures

baseline.comment: FRWO and other FMPs are not coordinated and lack inclusion of biodiversity conservation practices

target.comment:
INTER-SECTORAL COORDINATION MECHANISMS ESTABLISHED AT HYRCANIAN FOREST AND PILOT LANDSCAPE LEVELS
1 FRWO regulation on multiple use planning issued

actual.comment: Local Coordination Committees (LCCs) have been regularly meeting on a quarterly basis as the main inter-sectoral coordination mechanism at the local level. LCCs have been heavily involved in development of Integrated Management Plans (IMPs) which ensures functioning of the mechanism. Regional Coordination Committee (RCC) was established as the main driver for inter-sectoral and inter-provincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests. The latter makes sure a harmonized approach between all three Caspian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape through development and implementation of the so called "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy". The Strategy is under preparation after the first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline. Implementation of the "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy" will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme. The study on policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: INTEGRATED, MULTI-PURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN, INCLUDING sustainable land use plan defines a clear direction for the Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and supports mainstreaming biodiversity conservation

baseline.comment: Land use plans exist at the basin/catchment levels under FRWO management and similar plans exist for DoE management of PAs. However, a coordinated plan for production sectors does not exist

target.comment: INTEGRATED, MULTI-PURPOSE FORESTRY STRATEGY AND PLAN, INCLUDING Sustainable land use plan for Caspian Hyrcanian forest, that a) define biodiversity rich areas to be gazetted as new PAs and b) lay out appropriate land-uses and management practices to be prescribed in the adjacent production landscape

actual.comment: To ensure inter-sectoral and inter-provincial coordination for sustainable management of Caspian Hyrcanian Forests and adoption of a harmonized approach between all three Casian provinces towards multipurpose management of the landscape, a so called "Hyrcanian Forest Green Development Strategy" is under preparation. The first RCC meeting endorsed the need for this strategy and its outline. Implementation of the "Hyrcanian Forest Green development Strategy" will be mandatory for all government stakeholders through its inclusion in the 6th National Development Plan and the National Forest Programme. The study on policies, laws and regulatory frameworks to support multiple forest management in the Caspian Hyrcanian area is to be finalized in Q3 2015. The Strategy will include a zoning plan for the whole Caspian area which will locate the main land-use categories across the whole region. The Zoning Plan is also under preparation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Operational guidelines are being utilised to manage multiple land uses in forest landscapes, including improved forestry, small holder agriculture and livestock practices

baseline.comment: Forestry, tourism and agriculture sectors lack a coordinated approach to management

target.comment: At least 3 improved operational guidelines for: i) improved forestry; ii) sustainable small holder agriculture; iii) improved livestock practices and iv) sustainable tourism

actual.comment: As the sectoral guidelines should encompass best practices and lessons learned, preparation of these guidelines will be subject to slight postponement. Development of guidelines starts in the second half of 2015. ToR for national coordinating consultant is drafted ad under finalization.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Extent of integration of ecosystem values into production sector strategies and plans

baseline.comment: Ecosystem goods and services are utilised by production sectors, however their true ecological value is not understood or incorporated into the economics of key production sectors

target.comment: Systematic analysis of values of forests and externalities of deforestation and forest degradation incorporated into sector decisions and finance options identified to offset opportunity costs.

actual.comment: Ecosystem services in pilot landscapes have been mapped by application of a novel tool called "InVest" software. The software is used for the first time ever in the country which offers visual understanding of ecosystem services in two scenarios of present and future. The future scenario can be used as a supporting tool for decision making in pilot landscapes. economic values of ecosystem services are being calculated which will be followed by designing of financial options under Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES). The whole set of study is being conducted by a team of national consultants and supervision of international consultant. The study will be finalized by Q2 2016. The study has been involving relevant stakeholders (mainly Government entities) in training and consultation sessions and helped a lot in raising the awareness an building capacities on ecosystem services and their economic values .

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Enhanced institutional and staff capacity for implementing a multiple use forest management plan

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of training materials and best practices prepared and incorporated into FRWO management planning and induction courses

target.comment: At least 3

actual.comment: Project training plan is recently drafted. 2 comprehensive trainings on social forestry and ecosystem services values have been offered during the reporting period. Consultation sessions to develop IMPs, SABs proposal and Social Forestry Roadmap have been conducted through which training and capacity building modules have been offered. At least 300 people from different line sectors and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period. MoU is under finalization to be signed between the project and Training and Public Participation Bureau of FRWO for joint collaboration and inclusion of relevant trainings in the official induction and in-service training programmes of FRWO.

actual.comment: CD Scorecards were updated through consultation with the project team and stakeholders through which a cumulative score of 10 was calculated again. A Capacity Development Plan was drafted by the project which needs further improvements though consultation with stakeholders and the project team specially at the local level has been the main development change during the reporting period. Furthermore, holding consultative IMP sessions in pilot landscapes in which representatives of all stakeholder groups including local communities is considered as a very effective capacity development tool for engagement of multiple stakeholders in planning. Impacts of these capacity development practices will be measured in the mid-term of the project implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of FRWO and other sector staff trained and able to apply multiple-use forest management approaches

target.comment:
FRWO: 100
Agriculture: 50
Mining: 20
Tourism: 50
Animal Husbandry: 50

actual.comment: At least 300 people from different line sectors (forestry, agriculture, biodiversity conservation, tourism, water), ministry of interior, academia, NGOs and local community representatives attended all these training and consultative sessions during the reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Extent of implementation of the landscape level INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT PLANS / sustainable land use plan and lessons generated

target.comment:
AT LEAST 2 FMPS REVIEWED
At least 50% of identified actions implemented
A compendium of lessons learnt developed

actual.comment: Integrated Management Plans were drafted for all 4 pilot landscapes in a participatory manner. All stakeholder groups including government agencies, NGOs, academia and local communities contributed in development of IMPs through 14 different training and consultative sessions. IMPs need further consultation with local communities and the target is to approve them in LCCs and PPDCs by end 2015. Implementation of IMPs will start from 2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Use of a functional and effective monitoring mechanism for community based illicit felling and land clearing

baseline.comment: Community based forests require support for monitoring

target.comment: Effective monitoring systems in place to control harvesting forest resources

actual.comment: The study to review existing monitoring and enforcement mechanisms initiated and will be finalized in Q3 2015. The final conclusion of the study will be a number of proposals and a step-wise roadmap to adjust and amend existing mechanisms and make them more effective and aligned with multipurpose forest management requirements.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Replication strategy FOR SUSTAINABLE LAND USE PLAN IN PILOT LANDSCAPES that provide a clear intellectual means to expand the work of the project into the wider Caspian Hyrcanian forest landscape

target.comment: Replication plan FOR PILOT landscapes initiated with secured resources from central and provincial government by the end of the project.

actual.comment: Development of the replication plan will start in 2017 and its implementation will start in 2018.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community based integrated forest management piloted

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of activities included in the alternative livelihood development strategy that are implemented and percentage increase in income of community groups

baseline.comment:
0
Income baseline of community groups will be established during the first year

target.comment:
At least 4 different types of alternative livelihood activities such as beekeeping, NTFP enterprise, rural handicrafts, aquaculture, dairy product marketing etc. [to be further selected from the PPG shortlist during IW]
At least 15-20 % increase in income of targeted community groups

actual.comment: The alternative Livelihood Strategy is still under preparation in a consultative manner and based on in-depth and comprehensive data and knowledge that the project gained in all four pilot landscapes. Feasibility of low impact eco-tourism is being assessed in all four pilots and the study is expected to come to an end in 3 months. However, alternative livelihood options is being taken in two of the pilot landscapes. 6 women groups in Chehelchai are progressively making handicrafts and selling them under their name and brand. Handicrafts are made from local materials and have roots in their culture. Women groups have been able to generate significant amount of income as much as $5,000 during the reporting period. In project pilot landscape in Guilan Province, two youth groups was established which are taking alternative options for income generation. One group is developing its skills to do eco-tourism activities. The group has been able to take two groups of local tourists to the vicinity forest. The other group tried to establish a nursery to produce seedlings of forest species. Because of some legal challenges they have changed the idea and are trying to grow mushrooms as another alternative.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of community based forest management plans developed, AGREED BY COMMUNITY MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES and implemented

target.comment: 2 COMMUNITY BASED FOREST MANAGEMENT PLANS COVERING 30,000HA

actual.comment: FRWO has been practicing traditional forestry activities for several decades. There are significant resistances against application of Community Forestry (CF) in technical and managerial disciplines of FRWO. On the other hand local communities lack enough capacities to engage in CF planning and implementation. The project has organized an introductory session on CF followed by a comprehensive training on this topic aiming at building capacities in FRWO for CF and reducing resistances. Local communities have been a;so exposed to the idea during the reporting period. It's expected that development of CF plans will start towards the end of 2015 in limited areas first n Chehelchai and Sehezar pilots and then in Baliran. In Fariroud, Narvan cooperative is doing CF which needs adjustments to bring inclusiveness and equity. There seem to be willingness to apply these amendments. The project will start facilitation for these adjustments towards the end 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of people shifting to alternative livelihood options that reduce pressure on biodiversity

baseline.comment: Baseline to be collected in Year 1

target.comment: TARGET TO BE DEFINED IN 2014 AFTER DESIGN OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS PLAN

actual.comment: In total 8 groups of local communities (6 women groups and 2 youth groups) started adoption of alternative livelihoods to reduce the pressure over forest landscapes. Alternative Livelihood Strategy is under preparation and will be finalized in Q3 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: The rate of forest clearance under CFM as compared against non-CFM areas

baseline.comment: Baseline to be measured for both CFM and non-CFM in 2014

target.comment: Forest degradation due to agriculture, illegal cutting and livestock grazing in community pilots decreased by at least 50% in total pilot area and less than non-CFM area

actual.comment: The baseline for forest clearance is under preparation through socio-economic and forest condition assessment studies. Both studies will be finalized by Q3 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: PUBLIC AWARENESS OF FOREST GOODS AND SERVICES, VALUES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

target.comment: PUBLIC AWARENESS INCREASES 20% OVERALL AND 50% IN PILOT LANDSCAPES

actual.comment: The awareness baseline is set for all four pilot landscapes, vicinity downtowns and provincial capital cities. The shift in the level of awareness will be measured at the end of the project implementation again compared to the baseline. However, the project has developed "Communication and Awareness Raising Plan" which is under implementation The project has launched a bilingual website, 5 issues of newsletter, 1 series (4 volumes) of brochures on pilot landscapes, and a number of other awareness raising materials.
